The dehydrogenation of methylcyclohexane (MCH) is a widely used hydrogen storage technology, but nowadays, precious metal catalysts such Pt are used for this reaction and non-precious metal catalysts suffer from low selectivity and instability problems. Two catalysts, Ni20/TiO2 and Ni20/Al2O3, were prepared through the improved co-precipitation method and their dehydrogenation performance of MCH was compared. It was found that the application of TiO2 carrier could significantly reduce the acidity of the catalysts, and the nickel particles could be stably dispersed on the carriers, which could effectively improve the selectivity of the target product (toluene). In addition, the influences of different Ni contents, reaction temperatures, and weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) on the performance of the catalysts were also evaluated, and the results showed that the catalyst with 17.16 % Ni content exhibited high activity with up to 86.48 % conversion of MCH and 96.51 % selectivity of toluene, under atmospheric pressure condition with the reaction temperature of 375 °C and WHSV of 1.9 h−1, while 96.03 % and only 42.64 %, respectively, for the Ni20/Al2O3 catalyst. In addition, the catalyst exhibited excellent anti-coking ability, indicating that it has a promising future for industrial applications. Graphical abstract A Nix/TiO2 catalyst was prepared through an improved co-precipitation method, which exhibited the high catalytic performance in the dehydrogenation of methylcyclohexane. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Dehydrogenation MCH TiO2 carrier Stability LOHCs Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the gradually depletion of traditional energy sources, we are faced with the problems of energy, resources and environment, which makes the search for a sustainable and efficient renewable energy is a necessary way to achieve the "dual-carbon goal" at this stage [1,2]. Hydrogen energy has the advantages of no pollution, high cleanliness, renewability and high energy, etc., which makes it our first choice [3,4]. Due to the small bulk density of hydrogen, it is difficult to store and transport, so it is particularly important to achieve a safe and efficient hydrogen storage system [5–8]. It has been found that liquid organic hydrogen carriers (LOHCs) can store and release hydrogen through reversible hydrogenation of specific unsaturated organic compounds to generate alkanes, which should be an ideal method of hydrogen storage because of its recyclability, safety, convenience, low cost, and high storage density [8–11]. Methylcyclohexane-Toluene (MCH-TOL) hydrogen storage system, for instance, has become a crucial direction for researchers due to its reversibility, high hydrogen storage density (6.16 wt%), and relatively low toxicity [11–13]. However, its technological barrier is the lack of an efficient dehydrogenation catalyst, especially non-precious metal catalysts, which suffer from severe reaction conditions, low selectivity, stability and many other problems [11,14–16]. In recent years, various scholars have conducted research on the aromatic dehydrogenation reaction involving Pt, Pd and Ni-based catalysts [17–20]. And the addition of Ce [11], Ir [13], Sn [16], Mo [21], Al [22], Mn [23], and Cu [24], et al. to further enhance the catalytic dehydrogenation activity was also attracted a lot of attention. Pt-based catalysts are the most commonly used noble metal catalysts for MCH dehydrogenation reaction. Researchers [1] have explored the mechanism of dehydrogenation over Pt13/γ-Al2O3 catalysts and the results showed that the MCH intermediate had interactions with both Pt clusters and alumina surfaces, and the reconstruction of the Pt cluster and hydrogen migration occurred during the step-by-step dehydrogenation of MCH, which provides the optimal active site for the cleavage of the C-H bond; Yang et al. [9] revealed that TiO2 modified γ-Al2O3 could lead to the decrease of weak acid site density, the increase of the electron density on Pt, and enhancement of the H spillover on Pt, resulting the improved dehydrogenation activity; Boufaden et al. [21] found that Pt/Mo-SiO2 had better metal dispersion and was more efficient in producing hydrogen during the dehydrogenation reaction compared to monometallic Pt/SiO2 and Mo-SiO2 catalysts; Kousuke MORI et al. [22] demonstrated that the catalyst synthesized by impregnating Zn and Pt in Al2O3 can significantly increase the MCH dehydrogenation activity and reduce methane selectivity, and the loading of Zn gives the electron-donating ability on Pt; Zhang et al. [25] synthesized a Cu-Pt/S-1 catalyst, with an alloy of Pt and Cu that facilitated electron transfer from Pt to Cu, which thus exhibited a high hydrogen evolution rate of up to 445.3 mmol/gPt/min, a MCH conversion of 92.26 %, and a significant enhancement of the coking resistance. Jang et al. [26] found that coating a thin layer of CeO2 on the SiO2 surface to synthesize a highly reducible CeO2-SiO2 carrier through a chemical precipitation method, the oxygen vacancies formed on its surface would increase the electron transfer from CeO2 to the Pt active site, and the increased electron density would be beneficial for the desorption of toluene from the surface of the catalyst. Ye et al. [27] studied the Pt/GAC-S catalyst with good stability and non-homogeneous active sites of Pt components, which was able to achieve 63 % MCH conversion and hydrogen precipitation rate up to 741.1 mmol·gPt −1·min−1 at 300 °C, both of which were superior to other Pt-based catalysts. Although the Pt based catalysts exhibit the high ability of selectively cleave C-H bonds and poor ability to catalyze unexpected C-C bond cleavage, Pt is expensive and the Pt based catalysts also face deactivation issues. To reduce cost and increase the activity of MCH dehydrogenation, researchers have taken up the study of non-precious metal catalysts. Nickel based catalysts are widely used as low-cost and high active hydrogenation or dehydrogenation catalysts in industry. Thus, they might be the alternative potential catalysts for MCH dehydrogenation reactions. In fact, researches on some supported nickel based catalysts for MCH dehydrogenation are indeed underway. Song et al. [28] investigated the effect of Ni/Al ratio on the performance of NiAl2O4 spinel-based catalysts for the supercritical MCH catalytic cracking reaction and found that the hydrogen selectivity was only 50.4 %. Al-Shaikhali et al. [18] demonstrated that bimetallic catalysts Zn-Ni/Al2O3 displayed increased selectivity and catalytic activity towards toluene, and the lower selectivity for toluene over monometallic catalysts was due to the formation of CH4 and benzene from C-C bond breaking and methyl hydrogenation. Chen et al. [29] used titanium dioxide-modified Ni2P/Al2O3 catalyst for phenanthrene hydrogenation, at a reaction temperature of 320 °C, a pressure of 5 MPa and a WHSV of 52 h−1, and it was found that the selectivity of phenanthrene increased from 49 % to 68 %, and the modified catalyst contributed to the formation of small grains of Ni2P. Our group [30] recently synthesized Ni/Al catalysts that demonstrated an 85.6 % selectivity after optimization, with a liquid-time air velocity of 4 mL g−1 h−1 (equivalent to a WHSV of 3.16 h−1); Michalska et al. [31] demonstrated that the copper modified Ni/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited excellent selectivity for benzene hydrogenation in the optimal CuO content range. For the Nix/Al2O3 catalysts, the presence of a large number of acidic sites on Al2O3 would decrease the selectivity of the MCH dehydrogenation and lead to the carbon deposition during the reaction [9,17,32]. Thus using basic carriers to cover partial acidic sites on the catalyst is a direction for improvement of catalytic dehydrogenation performance. Based on the reported literatures, Titanium carriers might be a potential alternative. Misato Kosaka et al. [10] studied the effect of the presence or absence of electric field action on the dehydrogenation of MCH over the Pt/anatase-TiO2 catalyst to avoid the production of by-products such as methane and benzene, and found that the TiO2 supported Pt catalyst exhibited high activity and low production of by-products such as methane as well as carbon. Yang et al. [9] investigated the effect of TiO2 modification of Pt on Al2O3 supports with different TiO2 loadings on MCH dehydrogenation. The modified catalyst was found to make MCH adsorption more favorable for dehydrogenation, which improved the conversion of MCH (93 %) and the selectivity to toluene was higher than 99 % when the TiO2 loading was 10 wt%. In this study, TiO2 was used instead of the highly acidic Al2O3 carrier to prepare Nix/TiO2 catalysts, in which the loadings of nickel were 10–30 %, respectively, and were used in the catalytic dehydrogenation reaction of MCH to explore the effects of suitable conditions on the rate of dehydrogenation as well as the stability of catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts 2.1.1 Preparation of Ni-Ti-O catalysts The Ni-Ti-O dehydrogenation catalysts were synthesized through a modified co-precipitation method with 20 wt% Ni loading and Na2CO3 as the precipitant under constant pH conditions. Firstly, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (6.0588 g) and Ti(SO4)2 (20 g) were dissolved in 100 mL deionized water and mixed with vigorous stirring, which was labeled as solution A. 2 mol·L−1 Na2CO3 solution was measured in 100 mL, which was labeled as solution B. Secondly, 400 mL deionized water was added to a 1000 mL round bottom flask and allowed to be heated to 90 °C with stirring, then solutions A and B were each placed in a constant-pressure funnel and added dropwise to the round bottom flask simultaneously, accompanied by vigorous stirring and a homogeneous green flocculent precipitate (pH=6 ± 0.5) was formed. After further 30 min of stirring, the mixture was sealed and aged overnight. Then, filtering the above mixture, the obtained filter cake was washed several times with deionized water and ethanol. Subsequently, the solid was added into appropriate amount of n-butanol and evaporated naturally at 110 °C. Then it was further dried, grinding, and finally calcined at 500 °C for 4 h in a muffle furnace, to obtain the Ni-Ti-O composite oxides samples named as Ni20/TiO2. Catalysts with different Ni contents of 10 %, 15 %, 25 %, and 30 % were also prepared, noted as Ni10/TiO2, Ni15/TiO2, Ni25/TiO2 and Ni30/TiO2, respectively. 2.1.2 Preparation of Ni-Al-O catalysts For comparison, a Ni20/Al2O3 catalyst as also prepared through the same method as that for the preparation of Ni-Ti-O catalyst, just replacing Ti(SO4)2 with Al(NO3)3·9H2O. 2.2 Catalyst activity test The dehydrogenation performance for the prepared catalysts was tested in a miniature fixed-bed reactor equipped with a cooling system (shown in Fig. 1 ). Firstly, a certain amount of 40–60 mesh catalyst was mixed with an appropriate amount of silica sand and filled into the reactor. The reactor was sealed and pre-reduced in a flowing H2 at 450 °C for 4 h. At the end of the reduction, the temperature was lowered to the designed reaction temperature of 275–425 °C, and then, the liquid MCH was pumped into the reactor at a volumetric flow rate of 0.01–0.04 mL·min−1, and in the course of reaction, the flow rate of the carrier gas (H2) was controlled at 10 mL·min−1. The products were analyzed by a gas chromatograph model SP-6890 with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a capillary column model OV-1301 (50 m × 0.32 mm × 2 μm). The carbon balances were calculated to be more than 97 %, and the conversions, selectivities were calculated as follows: C M C H = ( 1 − M C H o u t M C H i n ) S T o l = ( 1 − Tol M C H i n − M C H o u t ) The meaning of each symbol in the formula is as follows: C is the conversion of MCH dehydrogenation reaction,%; S is the selectivity of toluene,%. 2.3 Characterization Agilent's Agilent 5110 Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) was used to determine the nickel content of the catalysts prepared in this work; the specific surface area was measured by Macklin's ASAP 2460 3.0 Surface Area Meter, and the specific surface area was calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, while pore distributions were obtained by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) algorithm; the structure of the catalysts was analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer from Germany, and the samples were scanned from 10° to 80° at a rate of 5°·min−1, with a step size of 0.02°; and the morphology, particle size and crystal surface of the metal particles in the catalysts was analyzed by a Philips Tecnai G2 F20 transmission electron microscope (TEM) with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV; X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis for the surface electronic state of the catalysts was carried out on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha instrument, which excites the photoelectrons using Al-Kα radiation; and the catalysts were tested for resistance to thermal stress by using a NETZSCH STA 449 F5 synchronous thermal analyzer from Germany; In order to evaluate the carbon deposition resistance of the catalyst, thermal gravimetric (TG) and Raman tests (Raman) were conducted on the Netzsch STA 449 F5 (Germany) and Edinburgh Instruments RMS 1000 (UK) instruments, respectively; the acidity of the catalysts was detected using the NH3-Temperature Programmed Desorption (NH3-TPD), and the instrument was the Auto Chem II 2920 instrument made by Micromeritics, Inc. in the United States. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) The actual nickel contents of the catalysts after reduction were determined by ICP-OES and the results are shown in Table 1 . It was observed that the actual nickel contents of the catalysts prepared through the improved co-precipitation method were relatively close to the theoretical nickel contents (i.e., 9.90% vs. 10 % for Ni10/TiO2, 17.16% vs 20 % for Ni20/TiO2, 30.67% vs 30 % for Ni30/TiO2, 18.09% vs 20 % for Ni20/Al2O3, respectively), illustrating that this method basically could realize the complete precipitation of nickel ions. 3.1.2 N2 adsorption-desorption measurement The specific surface area, pore volume and pore size of the loaded catalysts with different Ni contents after reduction are shown in Table 1, and the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves of Nix/TiO2 and Ni20/Al2O3 catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 (a) and (b). According to the classification of IUPAC, the curves exhibit type IV isotherms with the H3 hysteresis loop, indicating which possess mesoporous structure. The N2 adsorption amount increased with the increase of the value of P/P0 and there was a hysteresis loop phenomenon at P/P0 of 0.5–0.8, indicating that there was a large pore volume from the particle assemblies, and these pores possessed a wide range of pore distribution, which was confirmed by the pore size distribution curves. From the characterization results in Table 1, the n-butanol-treated samples can effectively expand the specific surface area and pore volume [33–35], and their specific surface area first increases and then slowly decreases. When the nickel loading is 20 %, its specific surface area can reach 134.53 m2·g−1, and with the increase of loading, the pore size first increases and then slowly decreases, indicating that a part of Ni is loaded on the surface of TiO2, while the other part enters into the TiO2 pores, leading to the decrease of pore size. The specific surface area of Ni20/Al2O3 catalyst can reach 260.72 m2·g−1, which is related to the large surface area of the Al2O3 material itself. In addition, the appropriate pore size and pore volume can reduce the mass transfer resistance of the reactants and products in the dehydrogenation reaction, which is favorable for the reactants to fully contact with the catalyst, while the products can be more easily detached from the catalyst, thus promoting the dehydrogenation performance of the catalyst. 3.1.3 X-ray diffraction (XRD) Fig. 3 (a) shows the X-ray diffraction patterns of the calcined Nix/TiO2 samples, with Ni contents ranging from 10 % to 30 %, synthesized through the modified co-precipitation method. The peaks at 25.4°, 38.4°, 48.0°, 54.7°, and 62.9° corresponded to the anatase TiO2 (PDF#21–1272) with the crystallographic planes of (101), (112), (200), (211), and (204), respectively, and no rutile TiO2 diffraction peaks appeared. The diffraction peaks at 38.4° (012) and 62.9° (110) corresponded to NiO species (PDF#44–1159), which were all very weak even for the sample with the Ni contents of 30 %, indicating that the NiO species highly dispersed on the carrier titanium dioxide. In addition, the crystallite size of the catalysts measured from the Scherrer equation from XRD peaks in Fig. 3 for the calcined Ni10/TiO2, Ni15/TiO2, Ni20/TiO2, Ni25/TiO2 and Ni30/TiO2 sample are 8.94, 6.45, 5.66, 7.85, and 8.67 nm, respectively. It can be seen that the Ni particle size was decreased with metal loading firstly, probably due to the differences of the surface area for the different catalysts, and then increased with metal loading, probably due to the agglomeration of higher metal contents. The Ni20/TiO2 catalyst possessed the smallest particle size of 5.66 nm, with the highest surface area (134.53 m2/g) and the relative moderate metal content. Fig. 3(b) depicts the XRD patterns of the typical sample Ni20/TiO2 before and after the reduction. It can be seen that the reduced sample possesses mainly metallic nickel (PDF#04–0850), indicating that NiO can be completely reduced under existing reduction conditions. According to the literatures [36–38], Ni0 is the active site for the MCH dehydrogenation reaction, and the amount of nickel (Ni0) in the reduced state and its dispersion in the carrier directly impact the conversion process. This implies that the smaller crystal size of metal species and their dispersion in the carrier skeleton are important factors. Fig. 3(c) shows the XRD pattern of the reduced Ni20/Al2O3 catalyst, and it was found that the catalyst possessed mainly a spinel structure (NiAl2O4), which is difficult to be reduced [41], with only a small mount of Ni0 species. Fig. 3(d) depicts the XRD patterns of the typical catalyst Ni20/TiO2 before and after the reaction. The main phase of the catalyst after the reaction remained similar with that before reduction, indicating the good stability of the catalyst. The crystallite size of the Ni20/TiO2 catalyst after reduction and reaction were also estimated from the Scherrer equation and the results were 7.55 and 9.53 nm, respectively, indicating that the particles possessed a slight agglomeration and growth during the reduction and reaction process. 3.1.4 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) Fig. 4 (a) displays the transmission electron microscope image of the Ni20/TiO2 catalyst after reduction and its corresponding particle size distribution. The morphology of Ni20/TiO2 is distributed almost spherically and with uniform size of approximately 5.18 nm, basically consistent with the XRD result. From Fig. 4(b), lattice streaks are clearly visible in the high-magnification transmission image. The crystal plane spacing measures approximately 0.35 nm, which is comparable to the anatase TiO2 (101) crystal plane spacing according to the standard PDF card. The absence of diffraction streaks for Ni metal may be attributed to detection difficulty or amorphous state [39]. Comparison of diffraction rings for Ni20/TiO2 crystals with PDF cards revealed (101), (112), and (114) in order from inner to outer, which is also in agreement with XRD result. 3.1.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) The complete X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectrum in Fig. 5 (a) provides evidence of the presence of elements C, O, Ti, and Ni in the sample, confirming that the successful doping of Ni2+ into the TiO2 carrier. Fig. 5(b) illustrates the detailed spectrum of C 1 s, indicating the signal peak of C-C at the binding energy of 284.4 eV, while the signal peaks for C-O and C=O are at 286.1 eV and 288.0 eV, respectively. Fig. 5(c) displays the Ni 2p spectrum with a peak of Ni0 at 852.2 eV, a peak of Ni2+ at 855.5 eV and a satellite peak at 860.9 eV, indicating that some Ni2+ was reduced to Ni monomer, consistent with the XRD findings. Fig. 5(d) displays the Ti 2p spectrum. With clear energy state splitting resulting from spin-orbit interactions, the peak at 458.2 eV corresponds to Ti 2p3/2 of Ti4+, while the peak at 463.8 eV corresponds to Ti 2p1/2 of Ti4+. The unique Ti-O bonding of TiO2 carrier causes a 5.6 eV difference in binding energy between Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2p3/2 [40]. TiO2 carrier with oxygen holes can migrate to the Ni surface and lower the system's surface free energy. Defects in TiO2 form a donor by capturing Ni2+ and producing Ni-O bonds that strongly attach metal Ni nanoparticles to the surface of TiO2, thereby resulting in a more stable surface structure. One of the main causes of catalytic performance enhancement is believed to be interfacial electron transfer between the TiO2 and metal particles. Fig. 5(e) displays the detailed spectra of O 1 s. The curve fitting analysis of the XPS pattern revealed two distinct O species on the sample surface with the binding energies at 529.7 eV (corresponding to Ti-O and Ni-O) and 531.5 eV (corresponding to the adsorption of O-H on the oxygen vacancy surface), with the former being the most prominent. 3.2 Catalyst performance 3.2.1 Influence of catalysts with different Ni contents on the reaction performances Fig. 6 displays the influence of Nix/TiO2 catalysts with varied Ni loadings on catalytic performances. It can be seen that as the Ni content increased, the MCH conversion initially increased and then plateaued. The selectivity of the primary product (toluene) increased initially and then decreased, whereas the main by-product (benzene) decreased initially and then increased. The best performance was observed for the Ni20/TiO2 catalyst with 17.16 % nickel content, with the MCH conversion of 97.01 %, the toluene selectivity of 90.43 %. These results indicate that doping with Ni2+ can enhance the catalytic performance of TiO2, but excessive levels of Ni2+ can lead to the decrease of toluene selectivity, probably due to the severe distortion of the crystal lattice, pore blockage, reduced effective contact area between the catalyst and the reactants, slow desorption of the product, and increased likelihood of product demethylation. 3.2.2 Effect of reaction conditions on catalyst reaction performance Fig. 7 (a) displays the product selectivity graph over the two typical comparative catalysts (Ni20/Al2O3 and Ni20/TiO2) under the different reaction temperatures. The results showed that the selectivity of toluene decreased as temperature increased. In particular, the Ni20/Al2O3 catalyst showed a rapid decrease with temperature, while the Ni20/TiO2 catalyst decreased at a much slower rate. For instance, at 375 °C, the Ni20/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited a MCH conversion of 96.03 %, but a toluene selectivity of only 42.64 %. In comparison, the Ni20/TiO2 catalyst converted at a rate of 86.48 %, with a toluene selectivity of 96.51 %. Because MCH dehydrogenation is a heat-absorbing reaction, the higher the reaction temperature is, the more favorable it is for it, but too high temperature can lead the aggregation of active species on the catalyst, so the catalytic activity decreases slightly with the temperature elevated from 375 °C to 450 °C. The catalyst exhibited optimal performance at a temperature of 375 °C. Additionally, the Ni20/TiO2 catalyst demonstrated significantly higher toluene selectivity compared to the Ni20/Al2O3 catalyst. It is believed that this increase in selectivity can be attributed to the acidity and alkalinity properties of the carrier. Additionally, Ni/Al2O3 is known to produce Ni spinel even in reductive calcination, and such a spinel is hardly reducible, which might be the reason of the lower selectivity of this system in comparison with Ni/TiO2 [41]. In summary, the dehydrogenation of MCH over the Ni20/TiO2 catalyst resulted in 86.48 % of MCH conversion and 96.51 % of selectivity towards toluene at a WHSV of 1.9 h−1 and a reaction temperature of 375 °C. Fig. 7(b) displays the impact of the WHSV on the reaction, revealing a decrease in conversion as the airspeed increased. It was also observed that the selectivity of the main product, toluene, gradually increased. 3.3 Comparison of the performance of the two typical catalysts Additionally, we investigated the stability of the Ni20/TiO2 and Ni20/Al2O3 catalysts at 375 °C with a WHSV of 1.9 h −1. The results are shown in Fig. 8 . The MCH dehydrogenation, catalyzed by the Ni20/TiO2 catalyst, showed greater selectivity than that over the Ni20/Al2O3 catalyst on a consistent basis. Upon a 6-hour reaction, the former catalyst demonstrated a conversion and selectivity of 86.48 % and 96.51 %, respectively, while the latter catalyst yielded a conversion and selectivity of 96.03 % and 42.64 %, respectively, indicating that the Ni20/TiO2 catalyst prepared by the improved co-precipitation method can well reduce the acidic sites and thus improve the selectivity, which is more interesting to study. Metal oxides are recognized catalysts for dehydration and dehydrogenation. Selectivity for products through a specific reaction pathway is often determined by the acid-base properties of the oxide catalyst. NH3-Temperature Programmed Desorption (NH3-TPD) testing commonly serves to analyze both the acidity quantity and strength of solid catalysts. The desorption temperature corresponds to the acid strength, where higher desorption temperatures indicate stronger acidic sites, and the peak area corresponds to the amount of acid. To investigate the acidity of the catalyst surface, two typical catalysts (Ni20/TiO2 and Ni20/Al2O3) were tested using an NH3-TPD method. As shown in Fig. 9 (a) and (b), the positions of the catalyst desorption peaks for both samples remained consistent but the proportion of the peak area differed significantly due to the use of different carriers (i.e., TiO2 and Al2O3). The acidic sites of the catalysts were classified into two main categories, specifically for temperatures ranging from rt-270 °C and 270–800 °C, as depicted in the Fig. 9, which corresponded to the weak and the medium and strong acidic sites, respectively. The Ni20/Al2O3 catalyst possessed higher levels of medium and strong-strength adsorbed NH3 than those on Ni/TiO2, which aligns with the temperature range of the MCH dehydrogenation reaction. Much higher selectivity of benzene (the production for the pyrolysis reaction) was obtained over the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, while mainly toluene (the production for the dehydrogenation reaction) over the Ni/TiO2 catalyst, indicating that medium and strong strength acidic sites might be the crucial factors for the MCH dehydrogenation reaction. Table 2 summarized the acid densities for the two typical catalysts obtained from the NH3-TPD measurements. Substituting the Al2O3 carrier with the TiO2 carrier caused a reduction in the total acid density of the catalyst from 3.42 mmol·g−1 to 1.76 mmol·g−1, with the weak acid from 0.90 mmol·g−1 to 0.60 mmol·g−1, and the medium and strong acid from 2.52 mmol·g−1 to 1.17 mmol·g−1. The use of TiO2 carrier has significantly decreased the medium and strong acid amount of the catalyst by more than 50 % compared to that of Ni20/Al2O3 catalyst, which has contributed to a remarkable increase in toluene selectivity during the reaction (96.51% vs. 42.64 %). After reduction, the acidity of both the catalysts were significantly decreased compared to the calcined samples, due to the reduction of nickel oxide with higher acidity to the metal Ni species. The spinel structure (NiAl2O4) formed in the Ni20/Al2O3 sample is difficult to be reduced, thus the difference of medium and strong acid amount for the two reduced catalysts was even greater compared with their calcined ones (2.52 vs. 1.17 mmol·g−1 of before reduction and 1.21 vs. 0.29 mmol·g−1 of after reduction), which might lead to a huge difference in the toluene selectivity of MCH dehydrogenation reaction over these two typical catalysts. 3.4 Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) and Raman test To examine the catalysts' anti-carbon accumulation performance, TG/DTG and Raman analyses were conducted for the typical fresh and spent Ni20/TiO2 catalyst as presented in Fig. 10 . The results indicate that the Ni20/TiO2 catalyst exhibited excellent resistance to carbon deposition. In Fig. 10(a), the significant weight loss of the catalyst at the temperature range of rt-200 °C by approximately 2.14 %, primarily corresponded to the desorption of adsorbed water. At 200–400 °C, a rise in weight observed was due to the oxidation of the samples at high temperatures, resulting in an additional 1.89 % increase in weight, with a maximum value of 322.3 °C observed in the corresponding DTG curve. The mass loss between 350 and 800 °C was negligible, implying the high stability of the catalyst. In Fig. 10(b), no peak was observed in the Raman spectrum of both the fresh and spent Ni20/TiO2 catalyst, suggesting that no carbon was formed on the catalyst surface after reaction. The TG/DTG and Raman analysis indicated that the Ni20/TiO2 catalyst, prepared using the modified co-precipitation method, exhibited excellent carbon resistance, which is demonstrated by the absence of carbon deposition after the reaction. In addition, this result indicates that carbon deposition was not responsible for the catalyst deactivation. 4 Conclusion In this paper, the impact of Ni-based catalysts loaded with Al2O3 and TiO2, which were prepared using a modified co-precipitation method, on the selectivity of MCH dehydrogenation products was studied. Both the type of carriers and Ni content significantly affected product distribution and carbon accumulation resistance. Upon comparison of the typical Ni20/Al2O3 and Ni20/TiO2 catalysts, it was determined that the TiO2 loaded catalysts exhibited superior selectivity of toluene, the production for the dehydrogenation reaction, due to the much lower medium acid amount than that on the Ni20/Al2O3 catalyst. The Ni20/TiO2 catalyst exhibited the 86.48 % of MCH conversion and toluene selectivity up to 96.51 % at a reaction temperature of 375 °C and the WHSV of 1.9 h −1, while 96.03 %, only 42.64 % respectively, for the Ni20/Al2O3 catalyst. In addition, the typical Ni20/TiO2 catalyst possessed high stability and superior anti-coking ability from the results of TG and Raman analysis in the air atmosphere. coredata.dc:description: The dehydrogenation of methylcyclohexane (MCH) is a widely used hydrogen storage technology, but nowadays, precious metal catalysts such Pt are used for this reaction and non-precious metal catalysts suffer from low selectivity and instability problems. Two catalysts, Ni20/TiO2 and Ni20/Al2O3, were prepared through the improved co-precipitation method and their dehydrogenation performance of MCH was compared. It was found that the application of TiO2 carrier could significantly reduce the acidity of the catalysts, and the nickel particles could be stably dispersed on the carriers, which could effectively improve the selectivity of the target product (toluene). In addition, the influences of different Ni contents, reaction temperatures, and weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) on the performance of the catalysts were also evaluated, and the results showed that the catalyst with 17.16 % Ni content exhibited high activity with up to 86.48 % conversion of MCH and 96.51 % selectivity of toluene, under atmospheric pressure condition with the reaction temperature of 375 °C and WHSV of 1.9 h−1, while 96.03 % and only 42.64 %, respectively, for the Ni20/Al2O3 catalyst. In addition, the catalyst exhibited excellent anti-coking ability, indicating that it has a promising future for industrial applications.
coredata.dc:title: Nix/TiO2 catalysts for enhancing the selectivity of methylcyclohexane dehydrogenation
